resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

fsaintjacques commented on pull request #6153: ARROW-7498: [Dataset] Rename core classes before stable API
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6153
 
 
   - Rename DataFragment to Fragment
   - Rename DataSource to Source
   - Rename *Discovery to *Manifest
   - Rename PartitionScheme to Partitioner
   - Rename Simple* to InMemory*
   - Rename SchemaPartitioner to DirectoryPartitioner

jorisvandenbossche commented on issue #6153: ARROW-7498: [Dataset] Rename core classes before stable API
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6153#issuecomment-573014747
 
 
   What is the reasoning behind the *Discovery to *Manifest rename? 
   
   For me, a "manifest" sounds something as a full description (listing of all the partitions, all files and their schema's), while the current FileSystemDataSourceDiscovery is only an incomplete description (eg only a directory name) and it *discovers* the full description (all files and their schema's in the directory, the partitioning of the directory)
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

users@infra.apache.org

kszucs commented on issue #6153: ARROW-7498: [Dataset] Rename core classes before stable API
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6153#issuecomment-573036135
 
 
   @fsaintjacques how about a bit different approach for Discovery/Manifest.
   
   ### Proposal 
   
   Remove the `*Manifest` postfix from the classes, and add `Materialized*` (or something similar/shorter) prefix for the counterpart classes, e.g.:
   
   ```
   FileSystemSourceManifest -> FileSystemSource
   FileSystemSource -> MaterializedFileSystemSource
   ```
   
   ### Reasoning
   
   Correct me if I'm wrong, but the end user will most likely interact with the `*Manifest` classes, because the user don't want to do the discovery manually, the user just want to describe the datasource. 
   
   If I recall correctly you were planning a DatasetManifest (DatasetDiscovery) counterpart for Dataset as well, mainly to encapsulate the boilerplate required to materialize/discover and unify the schemas of the datasources. So I'd rather imagine the following:
   
   ```python
   local = FileSystemSource(localfs, ...). # currently FileSystemSourceManifest
   s3 = FileSystemSource(s3fs, ...)   # currently FileSystemSourceManifest
   ds = Dataset([local, s3])  # currently this would be DatasetManifest
   ```
   
   The "plain" classes would be used for describe a dataset, then the `Dataset[Manifest]` would handle the required discovery logic resulting the materialized objects having all the required metadata (file paths, schemas etc) in memory.
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

   @fsaintjacques how about a bit different approach for Discovery/Manifest.
   
   ### Proposal 
   
   Remove the `*Manifest` postfix from the classes, and add `Materialized*` (or something similar/shorter) prefix for the counterpart classes, e.g.:
   
   ```cpp
   // for me it is also easier to mentally distinguish 
   FileSystemSourceManifest -> FileSystemSource
   FileSystemSource -> MaterializedFileSystemSource
   ```
   
   ### Reasoning
   
   Correct me if I'm wrong, but the end user will most likely interact with the `*Manifest` classes, because the user don't want to do the discovery manually, the user just want to describe the datasource. 
   
   If I recall correctly you were planning a DatasetManifest (DatasetDiscovery) counterpart for Dataset as well, mainly to encapsulate the boilerplate required to materialize/discover and unify the schemas of the datasources. So I'd rather imagine the following:
   
   ```python
   local = FileSystemSource(localfs, ...). # currently FileSystemSourceManifest
   s3 = FileSystemSource(s3fs, ...)   # currently FileSystemSourceManifest
   ds = Dataset([local, s3])  # currently this would be DatasetManifest
   ```
   
   The "plain" classes would be used for describe a dataset, then the `Dataset[Manifest]` would handle the required discovery logic resulting the materialized objects having all the required metadata (file paths, schemas etc) in memory.

fields.description:
DataFragment -> Fragment
DataSource -> Source
PartitionScheme -> PartitionSchema
*Discovery -> *Manifest

comments.body: I'd say Partitioner. Partitioning sounds more like it describes the output

For SchemaPartitioner (each directory is a partition value), I have

* StackPartitioner
* LevelPartitioner
* HierarchyPartitioner
* OrderedPartitioner
* DirectoryPartitioner

I'm tempted by DirectoryPartitioner.
IMHO OrderedPartitioner is best. DirectoryPartitioner seems misleading since all of the partition schemes parse directory names

I personally find "partitioner" sound a bir strange to my (non-native english) ears. 
It sounds as the one that takes an action to partition data, which is not the case here, it is only describing an existing partitioning of the data?
You are right that it doesn't partition anything.
